Award.AwardTitle: Language, Laws, and Labor Contracts in the 20th Century

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This resaerch will contribute to our understanding of how firms and workers allocate authority, and how this can be organized to increase productivity and reduce conflict. These questions go back to Ronald Coase and Herbert Simon, as well as the institutionalist school of labor economics. Outside of economics, our results will relate to the large literature in labor and legal history, sociology, and American political development that has concerned itself with the role of the law in the labor contract. Our new integrated data set of labor laws and labor contracts will be of value to both qualitative and quantitative researchers interested in computational linguistics, contracts, law, and the history of U.S. labor unions in the 20th century.

The productivity gains associated with successful firm-worker relationships rely not only on the terms of written agreements, but also on the background legal institutions that interpret, enforce, and elaborate such agreements. The purpose of this research is to explore the complementary roles of laws and contracts through the construction and analysis of a new data set on collective bargaining agreements. After merging the contract data with data on laws and firms, we use natural language processing tools to extract those textual features of statutes, court cases, and contracts that matter for economic outcomes. We then address two central questions. First, does the law affect written contracts? Second, do contracts affect economic performance?

POR.DRECONTENT:
We digitized a large  XX number of 20th century collective bargaining agreements contracts with Kheel, and assisted the librarians in indexing their collection. For public companies, we linked the collective bargaining agreements to CRSP stock market data and Compustat records. We developed and implemented measures of workplace authority, based on parsing contract language into modal and non-modal verbs, and the associated subjects and objects of the modal verbs. As validation we implemented these measures in a large (N= 76000) corpus of Canadian labor contracts, and showed that these measures of authority were strongly auto-correlated within a firm, and associated with a variety of collective bargaining outcomes.

We are continuing to collect data, and we are currently working to match the data with third party data sets.  The NSF supported necessary first step of digitizing the data.  The next step is to match the contracts to economic outcomes so we can see the causal effect of contract language upon firm performance and work well being. At the moment there is no research on this topic, and we have been working to buld meaningful measures of contract performance.

We have some descriptive results. In the first figure we show that Longer contracts are more detailed. We also find that firms with more employees have more detailed contracts.  The issue is what are the effects of these terms.  The grant support the collection of the data. We are currently applying for more grants to complete the economic analysis of the data so we may have a convincing result on the effect of contract language on economic outcomes.
